_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Big West Oil, LLC - North Salt Lake Refinery ("Big West Oil") has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training programs, equipment inspection programs, operating procedures, and engineering and administrative controls in our process. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable State and Federal rules and regulations. Our main goal is to take steps necessary to prevent releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, we have trained personnel and the appropriate equipment to respond to the release and implement control and containment strategies.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The Big West Oil petroleum refinery (the "Refinery") located in North Salt Lake, Utah primary products include gasoline, diesel fuel, fuel oil, propane, butane and isobutane produced from raw crude oil. The refinery has several regulated flammable substances such as butane, isobutane, pentane, propane, propylene and hydrofluoric acid (anhydrous) which is a regulated toxic substance.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps
Processes at the refinery regulated by the RMP are also regulated by OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. Big West Oil's PSM program includes detailed process safety information for each process to manage compliance with the requirements of each element of the PSM and RMP regulations to prevent or mitigate the accidental release of hazardous substances from equipment with the potential of affecting workers and nearby receptors.

Big West Oil conducts process hazards analyses to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage the hazards. Big West Oil uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic a

nd thorough hazard evaluation techniques. The analyses are conducted using a team of personnel with operations, maintenance and engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures. Recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures are provided by the team when deemed necessary.

Refinery operations are conducted according to standard operating procedures described in Process Safety Manuals and employees are trained on the operating procedures. Big West Oil ensures mechanical integrity of its processes by utilizing methods to verify materials of construction of process piping and equipment, performing regular testing of piping and equipment, and by conducting routine inspections and promptly correcting identified deficiencies. Changes made to refinery processes are properly managed, so all applicable personnel are familiar with the change.

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
Big West Oil's chemical-specific release prevention systems include temperature, pressure, and flow alarms; and automatic shutdown systems for process parameters such as high level and high temperature. Process vessels, tanks, and piping are equipped with pressure relief systems that route materials to knock-out drums and flares. 

In addition to the release prevention program activities, the Refinery has safety features on many units to detect a release, help contain/control a release, and reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. Big West Oil operates release detection, release containment and control equipment and release mitigation safety features where appropriate in the refinery process units. 

Emergency Response Program Information
Big West Oil maintains an Emergency Response Action Plan and a Facility Response Plan that describe actions to take in an emergency. Our emergency response program is based upon OSHA PSM and RMP guidelines. The refinery maintains an inventory

of spill response and fire-fighting equipment on site, and the facility maintains hazardous materials and fire brigade crews which train twice a month. The refinery participates in the Petroleum Mutual Aid Program in which area refineries would assist each other in the event of an emergency. A fully equipped HAZMAT vehicle and three fire trucks are also maintained on site for use by the emergency response teams. Additional mitigation measures are also in place to reduce any release that may occur. Big West Oil has also coordinated its emergency response program with the Davis County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire department and any potentially affected neighbors.

Five-year Incident History
The Refinery has experienced one incident in the past 5-year period involving an RMP regulated substance in a covered process that resulted in an EPA specified on-site impact. The incident occurred in September 2017 in the Alkylation Unit when a pipe leak released approximately 9,300 pounds of a flammable mixture resulting in a fire which caused on-site property damage. There were no off-site impacts from the incident. Big West Oil has investigated the incident and has undertaken appropriate responsive actions to address the findings.  

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Big West Oil continues in its program to upgrade our fire water system, add additional firefighting equipment and install fence line and process unit perimeter monitoring systems. The Refinery will continue to evaluate and implement changes as necessary to improve safety at the facility.
